quiz.title: Grade 12 Physics
quiz.subtitle: Unit 6, Quiz 8: Inductive Reactance - Advanced Concepts
quiz.subject: Physics

questions.question: Which of the following defines the relationship between inductive reactance ($X_L$) and frequency ($f$)?
options: $X_L$ is proportional to the square root of $f$
questions.explanation: From $X_L = 2\pi fL$, reactance is directly proportional to frequency: $X_L \propto f$. Doubling frequency doubles reactance. This is opposite to capacitors where $X_C \propto 1/f$.

questions.question: In an AC circuit with a pure inductor, the phase angle between the voltage and the current is:
questions.explanation: Pure inductor: voltage leads current by exactly $90^\circ$ ($\pi/2$ radians). Phase angle $\phi = +90^\circ$ (voltage leads) or $-90^\circ$ (current lags).

questions.question: If the inductance ($L$) of a coil is doubled and the frequency of the AC source is halved, the inductive reactance will:
questions.explanation: $X_L = 2\pi fL$. Doubling $L$ (×2) and halving $f$ (×0.5) gives: $X_L' = 2\pi (0.5f) (2L) = 2\pi fL = X_L$. Changes cancel exactly.

questions.question: When the frequency of an AC supply is very high, an inductor acts as:
questions.explanation: As $f \to \infty$, $X_L = 2\pi fL \to \infty$ (infinite reactance). High-frequency signals are blocked; inductor acts as open circuit. Opposite of capacitor behavior.

questions.question: Which mnemonic helps remember that Voltage (E) leads Current (I) in an Inductor (L)?
questions.explanation: ELI: E (voltage/EMF) leads I (current) in L (inductor). Complementary mnemonic for capacitors: ICE (I leads E in C).

questions.question: The voltage across an inductor is maximum when the current is:
questions.explanation: $V_L = L(di/dt)$. For sinusoidal current $i = I_{peak}\sin(\omega t)$, $di/dt = \omega I_{peak}\cos(\omega t)$. Maximum $di/dt$ (and thus $V_L$) occurs when $\cos(\omega t) = \pm1$, which happens when $\sin(\omega t) = 0$ (current zero).

questions.question: If a pure inductor is connected across an AC source, what is the power dissipated by the inductor over one full cycle?
questions.explanation: Average power $P_{avg} = 0$. Energy is stored in magnetic field during half-cycle and returned to source during other half. No net energy dissipation in ideal inductor.

questions.question: An inductor has a reactance of $100\ \Omega$ at a certain frequency. If the frequency is doubled, what is the new reactance?
questions.explanation: $X_L \propto f$. Doubling frequency doubles reactance: $X_L' = 100 × 2 = 200\ \Omega$. Assuming constant inductance $L$.

questions.question: In a phasor diagram for an inductor, if the current phasor is on the horizontal axis ($0^\circ$), the voltage phasor points:
questions.explanation: Voltage leads current by $90^\circ$. If current phasor at $0^\circ$ (reference), voltage phasor at $+90^\circ$ (vertical upward). Standard convention: positive angles counterclockwise.

questions.question: What is the reactance of a $10\ \text{mH}$ inductor at a frequency of $1\ \text{kHz}$? (Use $\pi \approx 3.14$)

scoreMessages.90: Excellent! You have mastered advanced inductive reactance concepts including phase relationships, frequency effects, phasor representation, and quantitative analysis.
scoreMessages.70: Very good! Deep understanding of inductor behavior in AC circuits. Review the relationship between current zero-crossings and maximum voltage, and how frequency changes affect reactance.
scoreMessages.50: Fair. Focus on: 1) Direct proportionality between $X_L$ and $f$, 2) Phase relationships and phasor diagrams, 3) Power characteristics of inductors, 4) Calculations with different units (mH, kHz).
scoreMessages.0: Start with the fundamentals: Review inductive reactance formula $X_L = 2\pi fL$, how phase relationships arise from $V_L = L(di/dt)$, and the ELI mnemonic.
